newsitem.title: AUSTRALIA: Airline passenger traffic from Australia up in Jan.
newsitem.headline: Airline passenger traffic from Australia up in Jan.

text.p: The number of passengers carried on international flights from Australia in January rose 8.8 percent to 1.29 million from 1.19 million a year earlier, an international aviation industry report said on Thursday.

The report, prepared by Australia's Department of Transport, said the number of passengers carried in January 1997 was also 16.4 percent higher than Janaury 1995. "This continues the trend of month-on-month increases since June 1991," the report said.
On an annual basis, the number of passengers carried on international flights increased 10.2 percent to 13.41 million in the year ended January 1997 over the year ended January 1996.

The report found inbound traffic was up 14.8 percent in January 1997 over January 1995, while outbound traffic was 18.3 percent higher. "Inbound passenger traffic of 678,000 and total passenger traffic of 1.29 million for the month of January 1997 were the highest ever recorded," the report said.
"This follows on from the record number of outbound and total passenger traffic carried in December 1996," it said.
The Auckland to Sydney route remained the busiest international service with 787,346 passengers flying that route in the year to January 1997.

Los Angeles/Sydney followed with 645,929 passengers and the Singapore/Sydney route recorded 513,627 passengers for the year. The report found Australian airlines accounted for 42.8 percent of the international market for the year ended January 1997, compared with 42.4 percent in the previous year and 42.9 percent in the year to January 1995.
